Award.AwardTitle: EarthCube Building Blocks: Collaborative Proposal: An Expanded Implementation of Cloud-Hosted Real-Time Data Services for the Geosciences (CHORDS)
Award.AbstractNarration:
While advances in sensing, hardware and wireless communications are permitting for previously unmeasured phenomena to be observed across unprecedented scales, it is the ability to act on these data that promises to transform modern geoscientific experimentation. The importance of real-time scientific data (data that are used as soon as they are collected) is ever increasing, particularly in mission critical scenarios, where informed decisions must be made rapidly. Many of the phenomenon occurring within the geosciences can benefit from better coverage of real-time data. Geosciences phenomenon range from hurricanes and severe weather, to earthquakes, volcano eruptions and floods and real-time data are essential to understand these phenomena and predict their impacts. The National Science Foundation funds many small teams of researchers that reside at Universities whose measurements can be of benefit to a better understanding of these phenomenon in order to ultimately improve forecasts and predictions. This is where Cloud-Hosted Real-time Data Services for the Geosciences, or CHORDS, fits in.

CHORDS makes it simple for small research teams to make their real-time data available to the research community in standard formats. By following a few simple steps, a CHORDS ?portal? can be created for a research team and their data can be streamed into it very easily. CHORDS can also be used to access data from large NSF research platforms like radars, aircraft, ships and operational networks of sophisticated instrumentation. Once these data are ingested by a CHORDS portal, they are exposed in standard formats and are available to complex scientific tools such as prediction models and other analysis or decision-support systems. Since the CHORDS concept will be exposed to small research teams at Universities, this will allow college students to learn about the importance of real-time data and how to incorporate these data into their analysis. By having more and higher quality measurements available thorough CHORDS, models and other tools can make more accurate forecasts and provide better-informed decisions to mitigate the impacts and improve the understanding of these phenomenon.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The EarthCube Cloud-Hosted Real-time Data Services for the Geosciences (CHORDS) project has aimed to simplify access to real-time geoscience data.  We accomplished this by developing a simple, secure, easy to use cloud-based tool (https://earthcubeprojects-chords.github.io/chords-docs/ ) that has broad applications across many scientific disciplines.  Through this project, researchers have shared their needs and challenges related to real-time data with the CHORDS team and together we have begun to raise the visibility of the science, engineering and technology associated with these data within the geosciences community. The project has also placed special emphasis on underrepresented groups through interns and diversity proposals at their home institutions.

By its very nature, CHORDS is an interdisciplinary concept and several geoscience disciplines have been engaged throughout this project. We have been able to connect with science and technology researchers in hydrological sciences, earth sciences, ocean sciences, atmospheric sciences and polar sciences. In addition, Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (STEM) initiatives and displays for the general public have used CHORDS to manage and visualize real-time data.

Real-time data streams are key inputs to operational forecasters and warning systems for the general public. CHORDS has built capacity among the community of real-time technologists and researchers and demonstrated the need and importance of lowering the barrier related to the integration of real-time geosciences data streams. The application of CHORDS technologies to precipitation estimates and flood forecasting has been explored within the project. In addition, through CHORDS Portals deployed in the African region and other third-world countries, many researchers in local communities have easy access to real-time scientific data for the first time. 

This project has allowed a new user community to flourish and develop new relationships with others facing similar challenges with real-time data in the cyberinfrastructure and geosciences communities. This work has also given the researchers the ability to monitor their data streams remotely and to recognize and correct instrument problems as soon as they appear. The portals have also given these teams the ability to download the data in easily usable formats, without requiring cyberinfrastructure expertise on their part.

The CHORDS tool developed during this project provides a reliable system for the archival, navigation and distribution of real-time data streams through an easy to configure and deploy interface. It uses modern standards for data and metadata formats as well as for data access. The source code for this project has been made open and available to the community through commonly accessible repositories including GitHub and DockerHub. Finally, many of the CHORDS data streams used during this project were issued Digital Object Identifiers (DOIs) during the course of this project so these data may be referenced in scientific publications. These DOIs have been transferred to the organizational entities for long term stewardship.
